awd_titl_txt: A Sleep Education Program to Improve STEM education in Elementary School
awd_abstract_narration:
This project will advance efforts of the Innovative Technology Experiences for Students and Teachers (ITEST) program to better understand and promote practices that increase students' motivations and capacities to pursue careers in fields of science, technology, engineering, or mathematics (STEM) by engaging young learners in authentic science investigations and linking them to STEM-related professions.  The project will address a real-world issue, sleep insufficiency, and its health consequences, as an innovative means to foster interests and engagement in science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM) among elementary school students. Partnering with the Catalina Foothills School District, researchers at the University of Arizona will develop, implement, and evaluate a new STEM education program that includes: a) a novel set of sleep science lessons developed in collaboration with Biological Sciences Curriculum Study; b) project-based learning experiences; and c) out-of-school exposure to STEM professionals and opportunities for students to present findings from their own investigations. The project will also develop a teacher professional development component tailored to the new program, and a strategy for increasing parental involvement in the learning process.  Portable devices will enable students to track sleep patterns in their own natural environments, and all data will be routed to a new, online platform, MySleep, which will provide real-time feedback, options for communications with teachers and parents, and data analysis capabilities. Through partnerships with businesses and organizations, a set of supplemental resources will be developed for parents and caregivers, including webinars and interactive presentations. Study of all these project components will provide data about strategies caregivers and teachers can adopt to promote among young students greater understanding of STEM fields, improved proficiency in STEM skills, and greater interest in pursuing STEM education pathways and careers.

This is a three-year design and development study that will employ a quasi-experimental design with a non-equivalent control group in years two and three to examine student and parent outcomes from field tests of  newly developed sleep study lessons.  Following the initial year of curriculum development, participants in the first cohort of field trials during year 2 will include approximately 220 students across four 4th grade classrooms and four 5th grade classrooms in one elementary school.   Another set of 4th and 5th grade classrooms in a school having similar demographics in the same school district will serve as a comparison group.  Following curriculum revisions based on findings of the initial field test during year 2, refined sleep study lessons will be implemented in the classrooms of approximately 440 students in the 4th and 5th grades across the same two schools in year 3.  Outcomes to be measured include student interests in STEM areas and careers, student proficiency in selected STEM-related skills, and level of parental engagement with their students' STEM learning.  Six features of the new set of lessons are hypothesized to increase engagement and motivation of 4th and 5th grade students in STEM-related experiences: (1) content (sleep) that is relevant to everyone's lives (students, teachers, and parents) and essential for healthy day-to-day functioning; (2) inquiry-based sleep science lessons using an evidence-based instructional model; (3) use of interactive educational software and various technologies (personalized) that allow students to actively engage by collecting, analyzing, and interpreting their own data; (4) a teacher professional development paradigm using face-to-face, online, and educative curriculum materials; (5) parental involvement/engagement strategies using a well-developed model of family-school involvement; and (6) out-of-school learning experiences including exposure and interactions with STEM professionals from diverse backgrounds.  The outcomes of this project will likely have broad impacts on both classroom practices with young learners and our understanding of how to engage young students in personally relevant studies that inspire them to consider STEM-related careers and the education pathways that lead to those careers.  The development of curriculum materials in both English and Spanish will assist teachers in engaging underrepresented and underserved populations in activities of high interest and personal relevance that demonstrate the importance of STEM learning to our society.

por.por_cntn:
Our Sleep to Enhance Participation in STEM (STEPS) team is an interdisciplinary collaborative effort between researchers in pediatric school psychology, engineering, public health, and medicine; field teachers; parents; and a science education company. Funded by ITEST NSF #1433185, the Z-Factor program, addressed the pressing need to increase and maintain STEM skills and interest of elementary school students.   The Z-Factor is an integrated STEM education program using sleep as a science conduit for 4th and 5th grade students. We have targeted 4th and 5th grade students because a comprehensive STEM program is needed for upper elementary school students before they move into middle school where research has supported that they lose interest in STEM, do not engage in STEM-related activities, and motivation for STEM careers declines. The topical focus of sleep provided students with the opportunity to solve problems and make predictions from and about real-world data because of sleep's universal relevance to all individuals. Accordingly, sleep deficiency is a public health epidemic that declines around the transition to middle school, has evidenced clear connections with poorer school performance, and has been related to health outcomes that reduce people's ability to be productive citizens in the workforce.

Given that this ITEST grant was a Design and Development project, the primary goal was to Implement an age-appropriate Z-factor program in the 4th and 5th grades that provides teachers with effective instructional strategies and materials to increase their students' knowledge, skills, and engagement in STEM and personal health.  One of the main objectives under this goal was to Develop a coherent set of five lessons and teacher guides focused on the science of sleep. In fact, rather than develop one set of five lessons that could be used in either grade, the curricular design process led to a separate set of lessons for both grades to reflect the grade-level Next Generation Science Standards as well as allow for multi-year participation to expand STEM learning opportunities. Below we describe the initial design process and respective products.

  The project started with a design conference that was led by project partner, Biological Sciences Curriculum Study (BSCS), with attendees consisting of university researchers (graduate students, faculty, and staff), members of the teacher curriculum committee, and members of the parent advisory group. An evidence-based instructional model (5E) was applied to design five standard-based lessons for 4th and five standard-based lessons for 5th grade students, spanning 8 to 9 class periods. In concert with these lessons, the STEPS team developed four interlocking components to make help students address a the public health issue with home, community, and school supports: 1) Community Connections (out of school learning experiences); 2) Home Connections (family involvement initiatives); 3) Educator Connections (teacher professional development (PD) resources and opportunities); and 4) Digital Connections (mobile technologies and applications to foster collaboration and data literacy). Each of the five lessons per grade comprises two to four activities. To test initial efficacy, these lessons were piloted in eight 5th grade classrooms and eight 4th grade classrooms. The project yielded a  teacher guide for each grade, and an interactive online learning platform called MySleep. As part of their projects, in the context of the lessons, the students collected their own data via sleep watches and sleep and activity diaries. With these data, they were able to investigate their own questions about what factors that impact their sleep quality, quantity, and consistency (4th graders), and the effects of sleep quality, quantity, and/or consistency on outcomes (5th graders). These data also provided up-to-date metrics about upper elementary school students' sleep patterns both across grades and over time (Li et al., 2020). 

As part of monitoring outcomes, students completed a 21st Century Learning skills assessment as well as completed surveys examining STEM attitudes; sleep patterns; and mood, attention, and prosocial behavior. At least one caregiver of each student was invited to complete surveys on levels and types of parental involvement; students' sleep patterns; and their child's mood and behaviors. Three hundred and ninety-five students participated in the baseline evaluation, of whom 191 had at least one parent respond. As this was a longitudinal investigation, students and parents completed post-assessment and followup surveys for up to five timepoints including into middle school. Data from these surveys, the STEM skills assessment, lessons, and schools have been used and are planned for conference presentations, dissertation research, and manuscripts.
